conclusion: To determine the initial distance between Car A and Car B when they collide, we need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph and calculate the distance traveled by each car during the braking process.
Car A starts braking at a velocity of 25 m/s and decelerates uniformly to 0 m/s over 30 seconds. Car B starts braking at a velocity of 15 m/s and decelerates uniformly to 0 m/s over 20 seconds.
The area under the v-t graph represents the distance traveled by each car during the braking process.
The distance traveled by Car A during braking is the area of the triangle under its v-t graph.
Distance of Car A = (1/2) × base × height = (1/2) × 30 s × 25 m/s = 375 m.
The distance traveled by Car B during braking is the area of the triangle under its v-t graph.
Distance of Car B = (1/2) × base × height = (1/2) × 20 s × 15 m/s = 150 m.
If the two cars just avoid colliding, the initial distance between them must equal the difference in the distances they traveled during braking.
Initial distance = Distance of Car A - Distance of Car B = 375 m - 150 m = 225 m.
The initial distance between Car A and Car B is 225 meters.
